'''''Eurovision Song Contest: Stockholm 2016''''' is the official compilation album of the contest, put together by the European Broadcasting Union and was released by [[Universal Music Group]] [[Music download|digitally]] on 15 April and physically on 22 April 2016.<ref name="iTunes">{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/eurovision-song-contest-2016/id1098144806|title=Eurovision Song Contest 2016 Stockholm by Various Artists on iTunes|work=[[iTunes]]|accessdate=13 April 2016}}</ref> The album features all 42 participating entries, including the semi-finalists that fail to qualify for the final.<ref>{{cite web|title=Official Eurovision Song Contest 2016 CD + FREE Coaster Set|url=https://shop.eurovision.tv/default/collectibles/cd/the-official-eurovision-song-contest-cd-2016.html|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=29 March 2016|date=29 March 2016}}</ref> The album also features the Romanian entry which was withdrawn from the contest by the EBU due to non-payment of debts.<ref name="romanian_disqualification" />

The '''6th British Academy Video Game Awards''' (known for the purposes of sponsorship as '''GAME British Academy Video Games Awards''') awarded by [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts]] (BAFTA),<ref name="BAFTA">{{cite web|url=http://www.bafta.org/awards/video-games/|title=GAME British Academy Video Games Awards|publisher=British Academy of Film and Television Arts|accessdate=2010-02-22}}</ref> was an [[award ceremony]] honouring achievement in the field of [[2009 in video gaming|video games in 2009]]. Candidate games must have been released in the [[United Kingdom]] between 1 January 2009 and 31 December 2009.<ref name="voting">{{cite web|url=http://www.bafta.org/awards/video-games/video-games-eligibility-judging,541,BA.html|title=Video Games Eligibility & Judging|publisher=British Academy of Film and Television Arts|date=2009-01-01|accessdate=2010-02-22}}</ref> The ceremony took place in the [[London Hilton on Park Lane|London Hilton]] on 19 March 2010.<ref name="BAFTA" />

==Categories==
Both publishers and developers were eligible to enter their games in fifteen categories, fourteen of which were awarded by a panel of judges. The categories are: Gameplay, Casual, Sports, Story and Character, Strategy, Best use of Audio, New Talent, Multiplayer, Best Technical Achievement, Original Score, Handheld, People's Choice (the only award voted for by the public),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bafta.org/awards/video-games/game-award-2009,1012,BA.html |title=GAME Award 2009 |date=2010-02-10 |publisher=British Academy of Film and Television Arts |accessdate=2010-02-22 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100215044612/http://www.bafta.org/awards/video-games/game-award-2009%2C1012%2CBA.html |archivedate=15 February 2010 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Artistic Achievement, Best Action and Adventure and Best Game.<ref name="nominations" />

title: Miss Universe 1981
text:
{{Infobox beauty pageant |image=Miss Universe 1981 Map.PNG |caption=Miss Universe 1981 participating nations and results | congeniality = Linda Smith
{{BAH}} | best national costume = Adriana Alves de Oliveira
{{flag|Brazil|1968}} | photogenic = Tina Brandstrup
{{DEN}} | date = 20 July 1981 | winner = '''[[Irene Sáez]]
{{flag|Venezuela|1954}}''' | presenters = [[Bob Barker]], [[Elke Sommer]] | acts = [[Peter Allen (musician)|Peter Allen]], Cast of [[42nd Street (musical)|42nd Street]] and US Naval Choir | venue = [[Minskoff Theatre]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | broadcaster = [[CBS]], [[WCBS-TV]] | entrants = 76 | placements = 12 | debuts = {{Hlist|[[Gibraltar]]|[[Namibia]]|[[Western Samoa]]}} | withdraws = {{Hlist|[[Indonesia]]|[[Papua New Guinea]]|[[St. Maarten]]}} | returns = {{Hlist|[[Cyprus]]|[[Fiji]]|[[Martinique]]|[[Portugal]]|[[South Africa]]|[[Saint Christopher-Nevis-Anguilla|St. Kitts]]|[[Transkei]]}} | before = [[Miss Universe 1980|1980]] | next = [[Miss Universe 1982|1982]] }} '''Miss Universe 1981''', the 30th [[Miss Universe]] pageant, was held on 20 July 1981 at the [[Minskoff Theatre]] in [[New York City]], [[United States|USA]]. [[Irene Sáez]] of [[Venezuela]] crowned by [[Shawn Weatherly]] of the [[United States|USA]]. There were 77 contestants competing for the crown, but Miss Mauritius got homesick and withdrew. The pageant originally was scheduled to be held in [[Guatemala City]], [[Guatemala]].
